factoid: Willarski entered the dark chamber to fetch Pierre.
Willarski was Pierre’s sponsor.
Pierre recognized Willarski by Willarski’s voice.
Pierre answered questions about the firmness of his resolution with "Yes, yes, I agree."
Pierre had a beaming, childlike smile.
Pierre’s chest was uncovered.
Pierre stepped unevenly and timidly with one slippered foot and one booted foot.
Willarski held a sword to Pierre’s bare chest while Pierre advanced.
Pierre was conducted from the dark chamber along passages that turned backwards and forwards.
Pierre was brought to the doors of the Lodge.
Willarski coughed.
The doors of the Lodge were opened by a Masonic knock with mallets.
A bass voice questioned Pierre about his identity, birth, and other personal details while Pierre was still blindfolded.
Pierre was led somewhere still blindfolded.
Pierre was told allegories of the toils of his pilgrimage, of holy friendship, of the Eternal Architect of the universe, and of the courage with which he should endure toils and dangers.
Pierre was called the "Seeker," the "Sufferer," and the "Postulant" during the wanderings.
Pierre heard conductors disputing in whispers about leading him along a certain carpet.
Pierre’s right hand was taken and placed on something.
Pierre was told to hold a pair of compasses to his left breast with the other hand.
Pierre was told to repeat after someone who read aloud an oath of fidelity to the laws of the Order.
The candles were extinguished.
A spirit lighted, which Pierre recognized by its smell.
Pierre was told he would now see the lesser light.
Pierre’s bandage was taken off his eyes.
By the faint light of the burning spirit, Pierre saw several men standing before him wearing aprons like the Rhetor’s and holding swords pointed at his breast.
Among those men was a man whose white shirt was stained with blood.
Pierre moved forward with his breast toward the swords, meaning them to pierce him.
The swords were drawn back from Pierre.
Pierre was blindfolded again.
A voice uttered "Now thou hast seen the lesser light."
The candles were relit.
Pierre was told he would see the full light.
Pierre’s bandage was removed again.
More than ten voices said together "Sic transit gloria mundi."
Pierre gradually began to recover himself.
Pierre looked around at the room and the people in it.
Around a long table covered with black sat twelve men in garments like those Pierre had already seen.
Some of those men Pierre had met in Petersburg society.
In the President’s chair sat a young man Pierre did not know, with a peculiar cross hanging from his neck.
On Pierre’s right sat the Italian abbé whom Pierre had met at Anna Pávlovna’s two years before.
A very distinguished dignitary was present.
A Swiss who had formerly been tutor at the Kurágins’ was present.
All maintained a solemn silence, listening to the words of the President.
The President held a mallet in his hand.
A star-shaped light was let into the wall.
At one side of the table was a small carpet with various figures worked upon it.
At the other side of the table was an altar resembling a church altar on which lay a Testament and a skull.
Around the altar stood seven large candlesticks like those used in churches.
Two brothers led Pierre up to the altar.
Pierre’s feet were placed at right angles by the brothers.
Pierre was told to lie down.
Pierre was told he must prostrate himself at the Gates of the Temple.
One brother whispered that Pierre must first receive the trowel.
Another brother said "Oh, hush, please!"
